text: Elena Kravchenko describes the structure of the novel as follows: "The structure of the novel, excluding chapter eighteen [...], forms a set of convex mirrors. The first and last chapters are *skaz*, the second and penultimate are prose, the third and the fifteenth chapters are poems, then again two mirroring Il'ia's narratives (4 and 14), the prose narratives (5 and 13), Il'ia's (6 and 12), verse (7 and 11), and Il'ia's (8 and 10). The structure 'folds' in the middle, at chapter nine — a prose entry, thus making it a 'centrefold', which holds the book together" (*Reflections* 53–54).

Such an ekphrastic title is borrowed from Modest Mussorgsky's famous suite of ten piano pieces, composed in 1874. If Mussorgsky's work intertwines music and pictorial art, in these chapters we see how visual art enters the written dimension of literature. Listen to a recording [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O31KPk5xnBg).

text: A Russian carriage with a long frame and no spring. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/47/Tarantass.jpg) Curiously, the word is spelled in Latin letters. Since the origin of the word "tarantas" is unknown, the author could be again playing on a fake "italianism" and/or recall the Italian city of Taranto (which is located in the south of Italy, yet not in Sicily). Ostanin suggests a connection to Vladimir Sollogub's 1840 novella *[Tarantas](http://az.lib.ru/s/sollogub_w_a/text_0040.shtml)*.

text: The first use of the tank in combat was in the Battle of Flers–Courcelette (September 15–22, 1916). They were deployed by the British. However, Ostanin notices an anachronism: the first use of the tank was indeed in 1916, but the battle on the Bzura in Poland happened on September 9–22, 1939 (67). Sokolov notes in his response to Sokolov that he has in mind here the first battle at Bzura. However, in "the new edition [of *Dog*]," he "has repaired this bit" ("Bol'shoe 132).
Comparable to the English phrase "Indian summer." Refers to an unseasonably warm and dry spell after the initial cold has settled in fall.

text: Achilles — the greatest of all Greek warriors, famed for his combat in the Trojan War and defeated of Hector. According to Greek mythology, he could only be harmed on his heel, hence the phrase "Achilles's heel" used to refer to a person's single weakness. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/ba/Achilles_fighting_against_Memnon_Leiden_Rijksmuseum_voor_Oudheden.jpg)

text: A reference to Zeno's paradox "Achilles and the tortoise." According to this paradox, Achilles challenges the tortoise to a race and allows him a head start. With both running a constant speed, Zeno proposes, the man will always take more time to reach any point that the tortoise has reached as they both continue moving. View a visualization and hear an explanation [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3vNlf2zGLaE).

Cf. A School for Fools' ending: "Весело болтая и пересчитывая карманную мелочь, хлопая друг друга по плечу и насвистывая дурацкие песенки, мы выходим на тысяченогую улицу и чудесным образом превращаемся в прохожих" (CITE).

text: A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin *caligae*, pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/cf/Caliga_Qasr_Ibrim.jpg). Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6e/%D0%9F%D1%80%D1%8F%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%D0%BD%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B2_%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8-%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5_1870.jpg) ([Miller 27–28](https://ru.wikisource.org/wiki/%D0%AD%D0%A1%D0%91%D0%95/%D0%9A%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B8%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%B8%D0%BB%D0%B8_%D0%BA%D0%B0%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D0%B8_%D0%BF%D0%B5%D1%80%D0%B5%D1%85%D0%BE%D0%B6%D0%B8%D0%B5)) Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 8 (R209/E103), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). text: Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Plyaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg). Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

As Ostanin suggests (69), the author mentions here the Moscow tramway line A, named “Annushka” by inhabitants, that since 1911 followed a circular lane on the ring of Boulevards (Bul’varnoe kol’tso). I put intertextuality intending annushka as part of a generic Muscovite discourse, but it definitively isn't precise here.why intertextuality?
Poetic: falling snow.
Vendors.

Such reference on snow falling on people appeared in A School for Fools too: "Если дворник с утра до вечера сидит в вестибюле и беседует с лифтером, а окна в вестибюле йок, что по-татарски значит нет, то дворник узнает, что на улице, а точнее сказать — над улицей или на улицу, идет снег, по снежинкам на шапках и воротниках посетителей, которые спешно входят с улицы в вестибюль, торопясь на встречу с начальством. Они, несущие на одежде своей снежинки, делятся обычно на два типа: хорошо одетые и плохо, но справедливость торжествует — снег делится на всех поровну." And: "Но ему, академику Акатову, мало кто верил, и однажды к нему в дом пришли какие-то люди в заснеженных пальто."

text: A really funny scene. Sokolov can be very ironic.
Humpback. The image of humpbacked people and animals appears several times throughout the novel (R152, 168, 180, 184, 187, 189, 200, 217, 103, 268/E6, 61, 66, 69, 89, 208).

The king of Ephyra (Corinth), Sisyphus, according to Greek mythology, was punished by the ruler of the underworld, Hades, for cheating death by tying up a god (in some versions Hades himself, in others Thanatos), thus preventing mortals from being taken to the afterlife. As a result, Hades tasked Sisyphus with rolling a boulder up a hill only for it to fall back to the bottom when it reached the top for eternity. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/43/Punishment_sisyph.jpg)

The reference here is to the Red Guards (Hong Weibing), a student-let movement who supported Mao during the first phase of the Cultural revolution (1960s). In USSR they were known as “khunveybiny” in the media. As Ostanin recalls (69), they used to cut “dogs’ heads” to political opposers. Here the allusion could also remind a Russian reader of the typical symbol of the oprichniki (a dog’s head, along with a broom).Animal motif.

text: Several major earthquakes have occurred in Albania. Following the publication dates of the aforementioned Russian newspapers, however, the earthquake mentioned here could have taken place in Himara on June 14, 1893, or in Shkodër on June 1, 1905.

text: A noble Albanian family in the 14th and 15th centuries. Gjergj Kastrioti (also known as Skanderbeg) led Albanians against Mehmed the Conqueror and the Ottoman Empire. The family eventually pledged allegience to the Kingdom of Naples. They may also be mentioned because their coat of arms features a two-headed eagle (reminiscent of Russia's own coat of arms) and the eagles on the bridge mentioned a few lines up. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a4/Coat_of_arms_of_the_House_of_Kastrioti.svg) Animal motif.

A white desert wine produced in Romania. According to Boguslawski, the name "commemorates the Russian victory over the Turks in 1789 near Ramnicu (Rimnicu) Sarat. The commanding officer of the Russian army, General Alexander Suvorov, was awarded the title of the Graf of Rymnik" ("Annotations" 246). Alcohol theme.

text: Chorea — a movement disorder belonging to the  dyskinesias group of neurological disorders. Its name comes from the Ancient Greek "χορεία" and was used to described the movements of those inflicted by the disease. Sokolov's first novel, *A School for Fools*, is dedicated to Vita Plyaskina, which refers to Sydenham's chorea (also known as "St. Vitus's dance, пляска святого Вита in Russian). Watch a video [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wTCnbga3sqg). Referred to several times in the novel (R171, 191, 205, 214, 215/E37, 74, 97, 113, 115).

The narrator here does the same. Shoe motif.

text: This mix of events and epochs suggests that time is rendered unstable. Time periods, like characters and locations, blur.

Holstein, located between the Elbe and Eider Rivers, was once the German County of Holstein (811–1474) and the Duchy of Holstein (1474–1866). Part of the Holy Roman Empire. Depicted on a historical map here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ea/Holstein_1477.png)

Irregular soldiers in the Ottoman army drawn from various ethnic groups of the empire. Known just as much for their brutality against civilians as for their prowess in battle. From the Ottoman Turkish باشی بوزوق (başıbozuk) ("one whose head is turned, damaged head, crazy-head"). Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e7/Basibozukchief.jpg)

text: A reference to the Batak massacre of 1876. The bashi-bazouks were sent in to quell the April Uprising and murdered thousands. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/db/%D0%9F%D0%B8%D0%BE%D1%82%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B8%D0%B9._%D0%B1%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%B0%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%B0%D1%8F_%D1%80%D0%B5%D0%B7%D0%BD%D1%8F._1889_%D0%B3%D0%BE%D0%B4.jpeg)

Boguslawski cites this line as a reference to General Joseph Radetzky von Radetz, who, during the Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878), "kept sending reports from Shipka that everything was calm there," when in fact his troops faced freezing conditions and attacks from multiple sides. Vasily Vereshchagin set these events in [a series of paintings](https://arthive.com/vasilyvasilyevichvereshchagin/works/397513~SHIPKA_all_is_quiet_Triptych_Reconstruction). Set expression: used a joking response.

A peak of the Balkan Mountains. Tsai Hsun (1885–1949), a noble of the late Qing dynasty. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c4/%E8%BC%89%E6%B4%B5.jpg)No luck so far. I'll keep trying.Ostanin (70) suggests to take a look at Russkoe slovo 10 February 1901; any chance we might find it somewhere?Possibly.

This whole section is a historical nightmare!but no harakiri in his biography, right? So could it be another one?

Also known as seppuku (from the Japanese 切腹, "cutting [the] belly"), hara-kiri is a ritual suicide by disembowelment performed to preserve one's honor in Japan. Samuri used hara-kiri to avoid being captured in battle, to restore one's honor after a dishonorable act, or as capital punishment. It is performed by plunging a short knife into one's abdomen and cutting from left to right, often in front of others. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5d/Seppuku.jpg)

August 1945. As the Soviet Army invaded Manchukuo, Japanese forces fled. This event allowed Russia to recapture territory lost during the Russo-Japanese War. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6a/Manchukuo_map.png)
A possible reference to the movie?

text: From Afanasy Fet's 1847 poem, "[The swallows are gone](https://www.culture.ru/poems/12451/lastochki-propali)."

A reference to the the Wandering Jew, whose name is said to be Ahasuerus. There are various versions of his story, but what is most relevant here are his alleged profession (shoemaker) and sin (taunting Jesus on the path to the crucifixion). The name may also conceal a reference to the nineteenth-century poet Afanasy Fet. In [Sokolov's essay](https://www.svoboda.org/a/25161164.html) on Velimir Khlebnikov, he calls the Futurist poet Agasfer. When Ivan Podshivalov brings up Klebnikov in an interview, Sokolov responds: "But you see, phonetics is the yeast, the fermenting agent of language. I start with a sound; sound is like a grain from which everything else grows. It's impossible to speak about phonetics separately from meaning. [...] It takes several years of preparation to understand Khlebnikov, but it is well worth it. After Khlebnikov, Sokolov will be easy" (Podshivalov, "A Conversation" 357–358).
Feathers, used for writing.

An 1829 poem by Alexander Pushkin. As Ostanin underlines, Pushkin dedicated it to the 16-year-old Ekaterina Vel’yasheva, whom he met in the Tver estate of P. Read the original [here](https://www.culture.ru/poems/5707/podezzhaya-pod-izhory) and an English translation [here](https://aleksandr-pushkin.su/podezzhaya-pod-izhory/?lang=en).

text: The narrator creates an odd human-animal hybrid here, mixing the driver with a rabbit, fox, and wolf. Animal-human motif.

A long coat often made from hare or sheep skin. Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/00/S._V._Ivanov._Peasant_in_the_sled._%281904-1905%29.jpg?uselang=ru) It plays a central role in Alexander Pushkin's novel *The Captain's Daughter* (1836), in which the hero, Grinev, gives the rebel leader Yemelyan Pugachev such a coat. Clothing motif.

text: Literary: words, text, verbiage.
This "муко" sound will be repeated many times in the novel. Such repetition will stress the closeness (paronomasia) of the words muká and múka (flour and pain).
suffix: шума. И что с того, что в туман

text: Colloquial: truly, clearly, authentically.

A non-existent, tongue-twister toponym. It also appears in other chapters with slight variations: Milokurekemovo and Malokulelemovo (R150/E2). This "муко" sound will be repeated many times in the novel. Such repetition will stress the closeness (paronomasia) of the words *muká* and *múka* (flour and pain).
